awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: From demography to diversification: population-level drivers of phylogenetic speciation dynamics across squamate reptiles
awd_abstract_narration:
Species diversity varies dramatically across the tree of life: some groups of organisms, such as beetles and flowering plants, contain far more species than most other groups of organisms. Understanding how and why some groups have come to be more species-rich than other groups is a central and unsolved problem in the life sciences. One class of explanations for these differences in species numbers involves the rate at which new species arise. Using tools from genome biology and computational data science, this project will identify the mechanisms that lead to different rates of species formation and quantify their importance in a major group of vertebrate animals.  The project will provide training in genomics, geographic information systems, computational biology, and biodiversity science for students and researchers at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral levels. Genomic resources and new scientific software developed for the project will be made publicly available, and a museum exhibit will highlight the ways in which genomics and computer programming are changing the way scientists study and understand the diversity of life forms on Earth.

This project will produce a novel synthesis between population biology and large-scale patterns of species diversity by integrating next-generation population genomics with a phylogenetic comparative perspective on lineage diversification rates. The project will quantify the genomic signal of several population processes to address how rates of population splitting and persistence influence speciation rates as measured on time-calibrated phylogenetic trees. These objectives will be supported by estimating phylogeographic and population genomic parameters across many species of squamate reptiles that vary in rates of speciation, and by developing new methods to link these parameters to diversification rates on phylogenetic trees. The project will also assess how organismal traits (life history, dispersal biology, population size) contribute to demographic processes that can influence the formation and persistence of incipient species. The project will provide a bridge between biological processes that occur at two very different timescales and will provide an understanding of how changes in populations at ecological timescales affect changes in biological diversity at deep (million-year) timescales.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The "amount" of biological diversity varies widely among different groups of organisms. Some groups of insects or plants, for example, have tens of thousands of different species, yet many other groups of organisms have only a small fraction of that diversity. This project explored how different factors influence the rate at which new species form, contributing to this dramatic variability in diversity observed among different groups of living organisms. While many previous studies have examined large-scale patterns in species formation across the "Tree of Life," few have looked at the underlying population-level processes that drive these changes over time. These population-level processes include attributes such as life history (the cycle of birth, growth, reproduction, and death), dispersal abilities (how easily individuals move across habitats), population size, and ecological traits (e.g., what habitats and food resources are used). To uncover these connections, the project examined the genetic structure within and between populations of reptiles, looking for patterns that might predict larger trends in species diversification across geological time. Key outcomes of the project included the finding that rates of species formation differ dramatically across groups of reptiles, with snakes showing particularly fast rates of change through time. These fast rates were also observed in other organismal features, including diet, with snakes having undergone shifts to a dramatically different set of food resources relative to lizards. The project also discovered new ways that researchers can use genetic information to study histories of populations through geological time. Surprisingly, some of the features that were predicted to affect the long-term dynamics of species had little impact, such as genetic dispersal ability. The project also found evidence for "blurring" of boundaries between species, which reflected a possible breakdown of some of the normal mechanisms that keep species separate. The broader impacts for the project included extensive training of students and other professionals across multiple career stages, including undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers. Training included skill development in multiple fields with broad scientific and societal relevance, including quantitative data analysis, development and analysis of genomic resources, and science communication. The project also yielded publicly accessible software and genomic data products. Finally, the project supported the development of a museum exhibit that explained how reptiles can be an outstanding model system for understanding biological diversity more generally.

 


Last Modified: 11/13/2024
Modified by: Daniel L Rabosky
